awd_titl_txt: University of Washington for R/V Thomas G. Thompson and R/V Rachel Carson Oceanographic Instrumentation 2021
awd_abstract_narration:
Requests are made by the University of Washington for Oceanographic Instrumentation (OI) on R/V Thompson, a 274-foot general purpose, global class research vessel, and R/V Rachael Carson, a newly outfitted 72-foot coastal research vessel, both operated as part of the US Academic Research Fleet (ARF).  In 2020, Thompson, in a COVID-shortened season, completed 202 funded days with 131 (65%) of them for NSF. For 2021, the vessel is scheduled for 277 total days with 224 (80%) days for NSF. Carson had 41 days in 2020 with 1 NSF day. For 2021, there are 71 days scheduled, 32 (45%) of which are for NSF.

With this proposal, UW provides technical descriptions and rationale for the acquisition of the following Oceanographic Instrumentation:

Network Time Protocol (NTP) servers (2)	$14,058	
-80C Chest Freezer	$8,795	
Niskin A (Thompson and Carson)	$20,450	
C-Nav 5000 Receiver	$13,717	
						$57,020	
Broader Impacts					
The principal impact of the present proposal is under Merit Review Criterion 2 of the Proposal Guidelines (NSF 13-589). It provides infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF).  The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project enhanced the capabiliites of the Research Vessels (R/V) Thomas G. Thompson and R/V Rachel Carson to conduct oceanographic reserach at sea.  This grant provided funds to purchase the following items to better support scientific research on the University of Washington - School of Oceanography operated research vessels:

  1. Two Network Time Protocol (NTP) servers
  2. New Niskin water sampling bottles for R/V Thomas G. Thompson and R/V Rachel Carson
  3. A new -80C freezer for storing scientific samples.

All items are shown in the attached photos.  These items all directly contribute to better quality scientific data from both research vessels.

The new NTP servers were configured and one is installed in the compter lab of the R/V Thomas G. Thompson and the second is carried aboard as a spare.

The new 10 L Niskin water sampling bottles replaced aging water sampling bottles on the CTD rosettes to ensure complete sealing of the collected water samples.

And the -80C freezer was installed in the main lab of R/V Thomas G. Thompson to replace an old freezer and ensure scientific samples are stored at the required tempearature while being transported back to shoreside laboratories for further analysis.

R/V Thomas G. Thompson is owned by the US Navy - Office of Naval Research (ONR) and operated by the University of Washington - School of Oceanography.  R/V Rachel Carson is owned by the University of Washington (UW) and operated by the School of Oceanography.  The vessels support oceanographic research funded primarily by NSF and UW.

 


Last Modified: 01/28/2023
Modified by: Robert A Kamphaus
